headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Mandy and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the O'Reilly 2009 Annual Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Tom McFall, sir, you may begin
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Mandy and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the O'Reilly 2009 Annual Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Tom McFall, sir, you may begin.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Mandy. Good morning, everyone and welcome to our conference call. Before I introduce Greg Henslee, our CEO, I'd like to read a brief statement. The company claims the protection of the Safe Harbor for forward-looking statements within the meani
componenttext: Thank you, Mandy. Good morning, everyone and welcome to our conference call. Before I introduce Greg Henslee, our CEO, I'd like to read a brief statement. The company claims the protection of the Safe Harbor for forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements can be identified by forward-looking words such as expect, believe, anticipate, should, plan, intend, estimate, project, will or similar words. In addition, statements contained within this conference call that are not historical facts are forward-looking statements, such as the statements discussing among other things, expected growth, store development, integration and expansion strategy, business strategies, future revenues and future performance. These forward-looking statements are based on estimates, projections, beliefs and assumptions that are not guarantees of future events and results. Such statements are subject to risks, uncertainties and assumptions including, but not limited to, competition, product demand, the market for auto parts, the economy in general, inflation, consumer debt levels, governmental approvals, our ability to hire and retain qualified employees, risks associated with the integration of acquired of businesses, including the acquisition of CSK Auto Corp, weather, terrorist activities, war and the threat of war. Actual results may materially differ from anticipated results described or implied in these forward-looking statements. Please refer to the Risk Factors section of the company's Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2008, for more details. At this time, I'd like to introduce Greg Henslee.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter conference call. Participating on the call with me this morning is, of course, Tom McFall, our Chief Financial Officer; and Ted Wise, our Chief Operating Officer; David O'Reilly, our executive Chai
componenttext: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our fourth quarter conference call. Participating on the call with me this morning is, of course, Tom McFall, our Chief Financial Officer; and Ted Wise, our Chief Operating Officer; David O'Reilly, our executive Chairman is also present. I'd like to start off by thanking all our dedicated team members who worked so hard each and everyday to make sure our loyal customers receive the very best service in our business. All they way from our company headquarters, distribution centers, regional offices and most importantly, our stores, our dedication to making customer service our top priority is clearly evident. All of you are to be commended on the solid results we generated in 2009 and I know we're all looking forward to continuing the growth of our company as we work to make 2010 another great year. It's now been a little over a year and a half since we began the process of integrating CSK with O'Reilly. During this relatively short period of time, we feel we've accomplished a lot and are clearly on pace with integration plan that we put in place directly following the acquisition. At the end of 2009, we had integrated many of the headquarters functions, renegotiated most of our supplier agreement, changed over and enhanced most of the product offering in the CSK stores, completely changed over 185 stores in the center of the country, we merged the Minneapolis distribution center into the O'Reilly distribution center in Brooklyn Park, converted the Detroit distribution center to O'Reilly systems and material handling, converted the Detroit Murray's stores to R systems, opened the Seattle distribution center, converted 141 of the 193 stores that are supplied by Seattle to R systems, along with a long list of other accomplishments necessary to integrate CSK with O'Reilly.Since the first of the year, we've completed the remaining system conversions in the stores supplied out of Seattle. We opened our Moreno Valley, California distribution center in January 18 and has since started converting the computer systems and has converted 148 stores supplied by Moreno Valley and hedges 90 to go to complete the Moreno Valley distribution area. These distribution center openings, along with the subsequent store system conversions, are the most important step in our integration process. As we'd outlined before, the 185 stores that were converted in the center of the country, which included the Minnesota, Montana, West Texas and New Mexico Checker Stores, along with the Chicago Murray's stores were very disruptive. These complete changeovers involve closing the stores for a week on average, removing the stores existing inventory, resetting the store layout, installing a new inventory, along with new computer systems, operational procedures and everything else that goes along with an O'Reilly store, we basically turned these stores into O'Reilly stores in one week time. This process again was very disruptive to the operation of the business. The conversions that we're currently doing at West are simply computer system and procedural conversions. These conversions do not require us to close the store and are not nearly as disruptive as the changeovers that were done in the center of the country. We're progressing with these changeovers at a rate of 30 stores per week and are being completed as we open our new Western distribution centers. To complete these, we send a tenured O'Reilly team member to each of the stores to be converted on Saturday before the stores plan conversion. This team member's job is to connect the computer terminals, get the system up and running and physically attend a data conversion, which builds the inventory, customer and accounting files necessary to do business on O'Reilly systems.These conversions take place after the close of business each Saturday night and we have a very qualified conversion and support staff here in Springfield that runs these conversions each weekend. On Sunday morning, the stores open on O'Reilly system and are connected to their new servicing DC. The team members of the store would have previously had training on how to use our point of sale system and the tenured O'Reilly team member acts as the trainer for the first week of business and stays there, at the store, for just first week. We then have a second trainer coming the following Saturday to spend another week with the store to make sure the store manager and team members not only have complete training on making point of sale transactions but also on all the various daily routine functions and procedures. So far, these conversions have gone very well and we're pleased with the results we're seeing. We remained very confident in our ability to complete the conversions according to the schedule we said as part of our integration plan. As most of you know, this plan involves putting a much robust distribution network in place in the western half of the country. This network basically emulates the network we have in place in the core O'Reilly markets and when completed, all of our stores will get the level of distribution and service and support that has allowed our company to prosper in both the do-it-yourself business and as a preferred supplier and business partner to commercial customers in the core O'Reilly market.Once we complete Moreno Valley, we will proceed with the opening of our Denver, Colorado distribution center in March then the opening of Salt Lake City in May, the relocation of our Dixon, California distribution center to Stockton, California in late August and then final step of these conversions will be the system conversion of our Phoenix distribution center along with the 151 stores supplied by Phoenix, which is currently planned for December 6. Like I said, these conversions are going very well and we're clearly not seeing the disruption in business that we were seeing with the complete changeovers that we completed in the center of the country.Now onto our fourth quarter performance. As I mentioned on our third quarter conference call, primarily for competitive reasons, the fourth quarter is the last quarter we plan to disclose the level of comparable stores sales detail that we've been disclosing since the third quarter of 2008. We plan to go back to reporting our company's total comparable store sales performance as a single consolidated comparison with our 2010 report. I know most of you read on our press release last night that during the fourth quarter, we generated consolidated comparable store sales of 2.7%. Our guidance estimate in our third quarter earnings release was consolidated comparable store sales in the 2% to 4% range. So we were within our range. This is slightly below the midpoint of our guidance due to a drop in our comparable store sales performance in December. This was partly due to the tough comparisons we had from December of last year and partly due to the macroeconomic factors that we assume, applied more pressure during the Christmas holiday with consumer spending more of their discretionary income and available credit on the holidays.Comps in the first quarter are on a solid trend and we think we'll see continued incremental improvements as the year progresses and we are able to take advantage of our distribution infrastructure in the western states. The stores on O'Reilly systems generated comparable store sales of 2.4% on top of the 6.2% comp increase they generated in fourth quarter last year. Considering the relatively tough comparisons, we're reasonably pleased with the performance of the stores on O'Reilly systems. The obvious exception to that comment would of course be the 141 converted Murray's stores, which had a comp store sales decrease of 11%. Included in these stores are the Detroit area stores. These stores operate in one of the most challenging economies in the country with unemployment almost 3x the national rate.It's hard to be pleased with the comp performance of these stores that as we've explained before they are in a state of transition and are moving to a more sustainable business model comprised of a healthy mix of both retail and commercial business, focused on auto parts and supplies as opposed to the substantial amount of non-automotive products these stores have previously been selling. Many of the core hard parts category are performing well in these stores as we drive this transition and as we continue to establish ourselves as an outstanding auto parts store for the do-it-yourself customers and as a great business partner and supplier to the commercial accounts in the Chicago and Detroit areas. Overtime, we'll see significant improvement in the performance of these stores.The 123 converted Checker Stores located primarily in the upper Midwest, Texas and New Mexico are performing well. The business model in these stores was more similar to that of O'Reilly and we're doing a good job in these stores, in these markets, establishing relationships with commercial customers and starting to build that side of the business. The Checker Store conversions in the center of the country generated an impressive 8.5% comparable store sales growth for the quarter. The western stores operating on the CSK systems generated 3.5% comparable store sales. Please keep in mind, as you consider our Western CSK store performance, that the 5.2% comp we generated in these stores during the third quarter was comparing to a 4.3% decrease in comps in the prior year. The 3.5% comp we generated in the fourth quarter was comparing to an 80 basis point positive comp in the prior year. So the positive sales trend we've been on in these stores continues.We remain very confident and excited about the opportunities we have to grow market share on both sides of our business in the Western states and we're looking forward to the complete rollout of our distribution capabilities as we continue the execution of our CSK integration plan. Generally speaking, we are very pleased with our performance to this point with the integration CSK. It's clearly represented a significant challenge and we still have a long ways to go to complete the integration but the pieces are coming together very well. Our team has worked very hard to execute our integration plan and our vendors have been very supportive of integration. I think the outstanding vendor support we've received is clearly exemplified in the improvements we've seen in our gross margin. We ended the year with a 48% gross margin compared to a 45.5% in 2008, a 250 basis point improvement.Tom will be giving specific gross margin guidance in a moment. But generally, we expect to be able to maintain these higher gross margin levels and our company will benefit nicely as we work to leverage our fixed cost by implementing our dual market strategy, allowing us to grow our sales in many markets, in which we feel CSK was underperforming. At the end of the year, we ended the year with an 11.1% operating margin, well on our way to getting our operating margin back to the pre-CSK levels and beyond. Having made many of the capital investments that needed to be made in order to enable the CSK stores to execute our dual market strategy, we're looking forward to getting back to positive cash flow generation this year. Again, Tom will be reviewing all our financials in detail in a moment. Just looking at our business from a very high level for a moment, the tailwinds for our industry continue to be the increasing average Asia vehicles in operation due to the improved engineering of newer vehicles and the decreases we've seen in new car and truck sales. The potential for continued increases in the number of vehicles on the road as the U.S. population continues to grow, the closing of OE dealerships, which potentially puts some of the service that was being done at dealerships into the automotive aftermarket. And for us, continued consolidation of the industry. At last count, the top 10 chains in the U.S. represented only 42% at the total parts stores and with many of our larger competitors modifying their business models to try and execute modified versions of a dual market strategy, we expect many of the weaker stores and smaller chains will fall under increased pressure, creating more expansion opportunities for companies like ours to see opportunity for continued growth. The headwinds are obviously the general economic condition in the U.S. with unemployment hovering around 10%, increased fuel prices. For example, at the end of 2009, we showed the average price per gallon of gas at $2.60 per gallon compared to $1.64 at the end of 2008, an almost 60% increase. This obviously takes more money out of our customers' pockets and has proven over time can put pressure on the total miles driven in the U.S. However, we see a lot of opportunity. Over time, we feel we can become a significant factor in the supply of parts to commercial customers in Western U.S. and at the same time, feel we can improve our penetration on the do-it-yourself side of the business in all the markets we serve. All 45,000 members of Team O'Reilly are working hard to make those things happen and we're looking forward to a successful 2010 as we work toward completing the integration of CSK and making O'Reilly an auto parts brand that will be easily recognized from coast-to-coast. I'll now turn the call over to Ted Wise for some additional comments.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Greg and good morning, everyone. Before discussing CSK integration, I would like to quickly review our fourth quarter expansion and then summarize our growth for last year. By design, we ended the year by installing 10 new stores in the fourth qua
componenttext: Thanks, Greg and good morning, everyone. Before discussing CSK integration, I would like to quickly review our fourth quarter expansion and then summarize our growth for last year. By design, we ended the year by installing 10 new stores in the fourth quarter. This enabled us to redirect much of the store installation department in our field team's attention to plan and start the store resets in the West. The fourth quarter expansion included three stores in North Carolina, three stores in Ohio, three stores in Wisconsin and one store in South Carolina and one store in Virginia. We also relocated two stores into new buildings, which brought us up to 14 relocations for the year. We completed 21 store renovations in the fourth quarter for a total of 53 store renovations last year. Then as I mentioned, in the last part of the year, our installation team's completed 27 store resets in the Checker and Kragen stores in the western state. New store expansion for the year reached our 150 store goal and covered 25 of our 28 stores we operate in.As planned to support our new distribution center in Greensboro this year, North Carolina let the growth of 29 new stores. Ohio had 21 stores, Texas continued to contribute good markets with 60 new stores. Georgia had 12 stores, South Carolina and Wisconsin end up with 11 new stores and our growth continues into Florida with eight new stores. Tennessee had seven stores. The remaining 35 stores were spread out in 17 additional states. As I've mentioned the past, the geographic coverage of our distribution centers allow us to more effectively and strategically plan and execute our store growth. While the majority of our growth is focused towards supporting the newer distribution centers like Greensboro and Indianapolis, we continue to see [indiscernible] good store opportunities within our more mature markets. Our continued expansion into markets like Texas, Arkansas and Missouri, provide additional leverage in our distribution centers, our field management team and our overall corporate infrastructure. The execution of our dual market sales plan to both the DIY customer and the professional customers gives us the opportunity from an O'Reilly store growth in many small, but very profitable markets that fall in our nightly distribution model.Since we are in the middle of the CSK conversions, we have decided to set our goal for new store growth next year at 150 installations. There are few new stores planned for the West Coast this coming year. Our expansion will continue to be more concentrated in the Eastern states, serviced out at Greensboro and Atlanta as well as the Ohio Valley state, serviced out of the NDDC and have nearly converted the Detroit distribution center. I would like to take this opportunity to recognize the great job that the corporate department and the teams in the field have done in planning, installing and staffing our new store expansions. Especially considering they have also been very involved in the CSK acquisition and the integration plan.Now for some additional remarks on the CSK store and distribution center conversions. As Greg outlined in his comments, the computer conversions in the and stores the expansion of the distribution centers is moving forward across the according to plan. Last spring, the Detroit distribution center was converted to start servicing the 79 converted Murray's stores in the Detroit area. It also played important role in supporting and supplying our new stores in Ohio and Michigan this year. The remaining converted Murray's stores in Chicago moved to our Indianapolis, DC and our distribution centers in Lubbock [ph], Minneapolis and Billings begin supplying the other 133 converted Checker Stores.As you may recall, this first group of Murray's and Checker Stores involve complete inventory lift, resets to the front display floor, new computer installations and going to our daily inventory replenishment. We have now finished installing interior O'Reilly packages in all these stores and with the exception of couple of stores, all the exterior signage has been converted to the O'Reilly Brand. Now moving to the West, the Seattle, DC was opened in November and as Greg described, 193 Kragen stores have been converted to the O'Reilly computer systems. Our Moreno Valley, DC opened last month and with all the same conversion schedule for the 238 Kragen stores that we get in Seattle of approximately 30 stores per weekend.Then in March, we will open a new distribution center in Denver and begin the conversion of the 84 Checker Stores in that market. In May, we will open the distribution center in Salt Lake City and follow with the 86 Checker Store conversion. And then in August, we will return to California to move our current distribution center in Dixon into a brand new 520 square foot building in Stockton. This will allow us to complete the conversion of the remaining 276 stores, again, following a 30 store per week schedule. Then in early December, the last piece in the puzzle will be converted to the system in our Phoenix distribution center. And the last Checker Store in Arizona and New Mexico will be converted. Since this will be the last conversion in the chain, the store conversions will take place on the same weekend. The end result will be all CSK DC and all CSK stores will be fully converted to O'Reilly system and the O'Reilly distribution model by the end of 2010.Our entire team has done a great job of planning and executing the conversion process in both DCs and the stores. These conversions, especially with the tight schedule we are working within, would not be possible without the contribution of literary thousands of team members from the core O'Reilly stores going to the CSK conversion stores for weeks at a time to help install and train. It is very rewarding to see our core O'Reilly team members work side-by-side with our new West Coast team as we implement our systems and our full dual market business strategy.Our store installation teams have started the reset at the front floors in the West Coast stores, which is entirely different and independent of the computer conversion schedule. Depending on the scope of the project, we will be able to do around 30 store projects per week. Immediately following the resets of the store fixtures and the new plan to grant each store will have interior remodel work done and the new O'Reilly interior decor package installed. The planning and the permitting for the new O'Reilly signs to rebrand the stores is well underway in the West Coast. Our goal is to have the store rebranding completed by the middle of next year, as well as any interior upgrade and maintenance needed. Now to add a few comments regarding the progress and growth of our business out West. With the exception of a few front room lines left to be converted, the product line upgrades and hard parts additions are finished. We have very good coverage in all stores that is supported by a larger inventory and strategically-placed hub stores. Of course, as the new DCs open, we gained the advantage of having over 100,000 SKUs available each night and sometimes during the day, if the stores are closed to the DC. Our DIY pricing has been adjusted to be more competitive in each market and our retail advertising, which includes print and radio is focusing on the increased product availability and more competitive prices along with continue to educate the customer to the transition to the O'Reilly Brand.The co-branding has gone very well, which helped us decide to rebrand the stores to O'Reilly sooner than what we had originally planned. In regard to the installer side of our business, the inventory upgrades have been important in growing our business along with improving our service level and providing great delivery service to our professional customers. Our sales team, consisting of full-time territory sales managers, and store sales specialists are very focused on developing sound relationships with our professional customers. We are very pleased with how the new O'Reilly team members and the conversion CSK stores have taken the new O'Reilly program and our are executing the dual market sales strategy in their markets. We are also very confident we will continue to have strong sales results and gain market share as the stores convert to our computer systems have better inventory availability with the new distribution centers.Now I'd like to briefly take a few comments to discuss our O'Reilly Managers Conference that was held last month in Nashville at the Granville Opryland Hotel and Convention Center [ph]. There were 45 management and a sales team member from our stores, distribution centers and corporate offices. The conference program involved both operations and sales training, which were customized to the individual store division. In addition to the O'Reilly training sessions, our vendors held a product and show [ph], as well as a number of key in-depth product training seminars for our team. Our general sessions were designed to recognize our high achievers, as well as to discuss the challenges and opportunities ahead of our company and the role that each of us play in achieving our sales and profitability. This is also the first time that our new West Coast store managers attended the conference and proved to be a huge benefit in helping them feel more part of the team and see up close what the O'Reilly culture is all about. Our management sales team's left Nashville very enthusiastic about the opportunities ahead of us and with an increased level of determination to gain market share this year in their individual markets. To finish my comments, I would like to thank our 45,000 O'Reilly team members for the hard work and their commitment to help make this a very successful year for the company. This success has been based on a true team effort and contribution and many of our team members were part of the CSK conversion stores. Others were very involved in the actual conversion and planning and execution. And core O'Reilly stores and distribution centers team member stayed totally focused on growing our core O'Reilly business. Judging from our company's performance, everyone did an outstanding job. And again, I would like to thank everyone for that job last year. With that, I'll turn it over to Tom.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ted. Now we'll move on to the numbers. For the quarter, sales increased $59 million, 5% over the prior year to up $1.17 billion. The increase was attributable to a $30 million increase in comp store sales, $31 million increase in non-comp new stor
componenttext: Thanks, Ted. Now we'll move on to the numbers. For the quarter, sales increased $59 million, 5% over the prior year to up $1.17 billion. The increase was attributable to a $30 million increase in comp store sales, $31 million increase in non-comp new store sales, flat sales in non-comp, non-store in sales and a $2 million decrease in stores merged and closed in 2008. For the year, sales have increased $1.27 billion, 36% over the prior year to $4.85 billion, the increase was attributable to a $189 million increase in comp store sales, $145 million increase in non-comps new store sales, a $4 million increase in non-comps, non-store sales. $935 million in a CSK sales for the period, we did not own CSK from the comparative period of 2008, which was January 1 through July 11 and a $2 million decrease in stores merged and closed in 2008.  For 2010, we estimate our total revenue will be between $5.1 billion to $5.2 billion. Moving on to gross profit. Gross profit was up 48.5% of sales for the quarter versus 46.2% in the prior year. The improvement was driven by the improved product acquisition costs negotiated with vendors based on our increased post-acquisition purchasing levels. For 2010, we estimate gross profit, as a percent of sales, will be 48.1% to 48.4% of sales. Inherent in this range, this $25 million of incremental buying synergies, we will see primarily in the first quarter, offset in part by decreased distribution cost associated with the ramp up of efficiency at our new distribution centers and pressure on the gross margin as the larger mix of the total business is done on the commercial side, which carries a lower gross margin percentage. Where we end up in the range would be driven largely by how successful we are at adding commercial sales in the converted stores, which will put pressure on the gross margin percent of sales but will be incremental to the gross margin dollars per store, which is our focus.SG&A for the quarter was 37.8% of sales versus 39.0% in the prior year. Excluding acquisition-related charges, SG&A was 37.7% of sales versus 37.9% in the prior year. Leverage on SG&A came from increased sales per store. On a per store basis, excluding adjustments, SG&A dollars were up slightly from the fourth quarter of 2008. That slight increase is comprised of decreases in headquarters, advertising and general store expenses, offset by increases in store payroll related to the cost of store conversions and the cost of launch in additional commercial programs and converted stores. For 2010, we expect SG&A dollars per store to be slightly down. We'll continue to invest significant dollars in store conversions, training and new commercial programs where we expect this to be fully offset by increased synergies on headquarters and advertising and increased sales driven by our store investment made in 2009.Operating margin for the quarter was 10.7% of sales, an improvement of 345 basis points over the prior year. Excluding acquisition adjustment, the quarterly operating margin increased 244 basis points. For 2009, operating margin was 11.1% of sales and is quickly closing in on our pre-acquisition outcome operating margin of 11.8% for the period ended June, 2008. We're very encouraged on the rapid progress we've made in returning our operating margin to pre-acquisition levels in such a relatively short period of time. We expect our operating margins for 2010 to exceed the pre-acquisition of operating margins.A little bit about interest, net interest expense for the quarter was $11 million, which was $2 million less than prior year and lower LIBOR offset in part by higher debt levels. For 2010, we expect net interest expense of $41 million to $43 million based and lower average debt levels. This estimate is also subject to unforeseen changes in LIBOR levels to the extent our debt is not swapped in fixed rates. The tax provision for the quarter was 38.0% of pretax income as compared to 37.7% in the prior year. The fourth quarter results were favorable to our third quarter guidance due to the favorable resolution of certain tax issues. For 2010, we expect our tax rate as a percent of pretax income to be 38.0% up to 38.4% as compared to 38.1% for all of 2009. Where we fall within this range will be dependent on resolution of open tax year audit that occur during the year.Adjusted diluted earnings per share for the quarter was $0.52 per share, which represents an increase of 41% over the fourth quarter 2008. For the year, adjusted diluted earnings per share was $2.26, a 38% increase over the prior year. Now we'll move on to the balance sheet. The average inventory per store at the end of the year was $559,000, which was a 17% increase from the prior year average of $478,000. The increase was in the CSK stores as the core O'Reilly stores average inventory approximated historical levels. The increase was the result of the changeovers at CSK storage, which added a much wider breadth of SKUs available at each store combined with stores on the CSK system receiving only one-stock order a week, which necessitates more stocking debt.In 2009, we intentionally flooded the CSK stores with hard parts to get them back in the hard parts business. In 2010, we are focused on the refining inventory mix at the CSK stores and as a new distribution centers come online, we will be able to reduce the stocking debt at the CSK stores. Based on these 2010 initiatives, we expect only increase our total inventory investment slightly in 2010, despite opening 150 new stores and adding three distribution centers. Our reserve for LIFO at the end of the quarter was $8.7 million, which was a decrease of $4.1 million in the previous quarter. This change in our last pie to LIFO inventory reserve did not have a material impact on gross margin for the fourth quarter. Our accounts payable of $818 million was 42.8% of inventory compared to 46.9% in the prior year. Our AP to inventory ratio at the end of 2008 benefited from special extend dating and changeover orders. In 2010, we expect our AP to inventory ratio will continue to be under pressure as we work excess inventory out of and through the system.Capital expenditures were $98 million for the quarter, bringing the year-to-date total to $415 million, which was within our estimate of the 2009 CapEx spend of $400 million to $420 million we discussed on the third quarter call. For 2010, we anticipate capital expenditures will be $400 million to $440 million as we complete our DC projects and continue to invest heavily in store conversions. Excluding conversion CapEx, maintenance CapEx in our 150 new stores would be an approximately the $250 million range. Depreciation and amortization for the quarter was $37 million and $148 million respectively. For 2010, we expect depreciation and amortization to be $154 million to $159 million. Moving on to debt. Total borrowings were $791 billion at the end of December this year compared to $733 million at the end of 2008. The increased debt of $58 million has been used to fund new store growth at the core O'Reilly stores and the conversion of investment including book CapEx and net inventory at required CSK stores. However, the majority of these investments had been covered by internally generated cash flow. For the year, we've increased our debt outstanding on our ABL-backed 62 $5 million [ph] . However, because of the increase in our borrowing base, availability under the revolver has actually increased slightly to $445 million, providing us with ample available credit. For 2010, we expect to reduce our total outstanding borrowings by $150 million to $250 million. Including this reduction is our plan redemption of the $100 million legacy, CSK convertible note in December. Our plan is to fund this with our existing ABL [ph], which will still as significant financial flexibility.Now for some other financial information. Cash flow from operating activities for the quarter was a use of $4 million versus the positive $9 million in the prior year. Both numbers reflect the seasonal nature of our cash flows from operating activity. For the year, cash flow from operating activity decreased $30 million to $285 million, driven by the higher income, offset by our large investment in net inventory. For the year, free cash flow was a use of $130 million as we invested heavily on inventory and CapEx to the DC expansion and store conversions. We expect free cash flow to swing to a positive $120 million to $150 million in 2010 as we continue, again, invest heavily in CapEx but did not have a significant investment in net inventory.CapEx with the DC expansion and store conversions. We expect free cash flow to swing to a positive $120 million to $150 million in 2010 as we continue again, invest heavily in CapEx but do not have a significant investment in net inventory.Stock option expense for the quarter was $3.2 million compared to $2.5 million in the prior year and the year-to-date stock option expense was $13.5 million compared to $8 million in the prior year. With the increase being driven by the options issued in connection with the CSK acquisition. For 2010, we expect stock option expense to be approximately $16 million. We finished by recapping our overall guidance. For the first quarter, our comparable store sales guidance is 2% to 4%. And for the year, our comparable store sales guidance increases 3% to 5% as we see the positive impact of more converted CSK stores. Our GAAP diluted earnings per share guidance for the first quarter is from $0.56 to $0.60 on $139.5 million shares and our adjusted GAAP diluted earnings per share guidance for the full year is from $2.50 to $2.56 on a 140.3 million shares. At this time, I would like to ask Mandy, our operator to come back and we'll be happy to answer your questions.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We will now take our first question from the line of Gary Balter with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We will now take our first question from the line of Gary Balter with Credit Suisse.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is actually Matt Gardner. A couple of questions on the conversion process. As we think about the evolution of the performance of those converted stores as you roll them out. Can we use Checkers, the Checkers progression and sort of what you think the
componenttext: This is actually Matt Gardner. A couple of questions on the conversion process. As we think about the evolution of the performance of those converted stores as you roll them out. Can we use Checkers, the Checkers progression and sort of what you think the normal run rate would be, say, going back a couple of quarters, they started out negative and they sort of got back into positive range two quarters out and now you're up 8.5. How sort of atypical is that for most of the converted stores as they roll out?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said, the stores that we converted in the center of the country are much different from a pure conversion standpoint. Although the ultimate result we feel would be very similar. I think the comparison there would be that in the stores in the c
componenttext: Well, as we said, the stores that we converted in the center of the country are much different from a pure conversion standpoint. Although the ultimate result we feel would be very similar. I think the comparison there would be that in the stores in the center of the country, we saw pretty significant dips in performance that were the result of closing the store for a week as we did the conversion and then just the shock of training, all the products being relocated in the store. A very disruptive process that caused the sales to be soft and for the stores not to comp very well for maybe a four-week period or maybe even longer than that in some cases. We won't see the downturn in sales to the degree that we did in the center of the country stores, in the western stores but I think the end result will be similar and that varies by market. We have more opportunity in some markets than others, obviously. But I don't think it would be unreasonable to ultimately expect performance comparable to what we're seeing now in the Checker Stores.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as you've done the Schuck's stores over the last sort of couple of months since November. Any surprises there, positive or negative?
componenttext: And as you've done the Schuck's stores over the last sort of couple of months since November. Any surprises there, positive or negative?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. We knew, when we did the Schuck's stores when we did that we were going to be comparing to a unusual weather period in Seattle last year, when we had a huge snowstorm in Seattle that drove a lot of tire chain sales and other things that you wouldn't n
componenttext: No. We knew, when we did the Schuck's stores when we did that we were going to be comparing to a unusual weather period in Seattle last year, when we had a huge snowstorm in Seattle that drove a lot of tire chain sales and other things that you wouldn't normally sell. From a sales trend perspective, we were very happy with the lack of disruption in the Seattle converted stores and have been pleased with the conversion progress, not only in Seattle but also the performance of the stores in Southern California, they're being converted to be supplied out of Moreno Valley.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the SG&A front, you got the guidance on a per store basis, I guess it should be up slightly versus 2009. How do we think about how the spending evolves throughout the quarter? Is there any lumpiness to SG&A spend related to the DCs as they roll ou
componenttext: Just on the SG&A front, you got the guidance on a per store basis, I guess it should be up slightly versus 2009. How do we think about how the spending evolves throughout the quarter? Is there any lumpiness to SG&A spend related to the DCs as they roll out? When do you start to see some of the elevated SG&A expense start to drop off as you get past the conversion process? Is it a late 2010 event, is most of it going to come in 2011?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. First thing I'd like to say is in my prepared comments, distribution costs I inadvertently said that we are going to see a decrease in distribution costs. Of course, that's incorrect. We expect to see it as a percent of sales an increase this
componenttext: This is Tom. First thing I'd like to say is in my prepared comments, distribution costs I inadvertently said that we are going to see a decrease in distribution costs. Of course, that's incorrect. We expect to see it as a percent of sales an increase this year as we open new DCs that are inefficient. Now let me move on to your specific question. Distribution costs will be -- are included in gross margin. But as we open more DCs and we have more DCs that aren't fully efficient, there'll be more of a drag in the end of the year. But our distribution teams will work quickly to get the training done that needs to happen to get them efficient again. When we look at SG&A, on a regional basis, SG&A will be very lumpy. But on total, because we're doing about the same number of conversions each month, we'd expect it to be relatively consistent across the year with the exception of our normal seasonality, which lines up with the stronger sales in the second and third quarter.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just lastly on the gross margin line, if we go back to the second quarter, I think the guidance that you had for the back half of the year assumes gross margin back off a little bit. The gross margin will come down a little bit just related to commodity c
componenttext: Just lastly on the gross margin line, if we go back to the second quarter, I think the guidance that you had for the back half of the year assumes gross margin back off a little bit. The gross margin will come down a little bit just related to commodity costs. And I think we ended up actually being above what the 2Q run rate was. I'm just curious as to what you think -- what was sort of the incremental driver of the stronger gross margin as we went into the back half of the year?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we see -- obviously, a lot of it has to do with finishing up some deals with major vendors and getting the accounting right. But what we also see is when we have slower sales in the fourth and first quarter, driven by fewer commodity weather items, i
componenttext: What we see -- obviously, a lot of it has to do with finishing up some deals with major vendors and getting the accounting right. But what we also see is when we have slower sales in the fourth and first quarter, driven by fewer commodity weather items, it hurts our topline but helps our gross margin percentage because those products tend to not carry this as high a gross margin percentage.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question is from Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, Greg, can you just talk a little bit about the competitive dynamics, especially in the commercial side that the Western CSK stores are going to encounter as you ramp up that commercial business?
componenttext: First of all, Greg, can you just talk a little bit about the competitive dynamics, especially in the commercial side that the Western CSK stores are going to encounter as you ramp up that commercial business?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Well, there's plenty of competitors out there as there are in every market. There's several smaller chains out there that do a good job in commercial. There's several, what we call, two-step operations that basically exists just to service commercia
componenttext: Sure. Well, there's plenty of competitors out there as there are in every market. There's several smaller chains out there that do a good job in commercial. There's several, what we call, two-step operations that basically exists just to service commercial customers and they're all tough competitors. So we take them one at a time by market, evaluate their strategy pricing, inventory, the service levels they're able to provide and come up with a combination for us that allows us to incrementally develop relationships with customers and start working to take our fair share of the market.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a clarification on the guidance, I think this time last year, you basically guided 2009 to about $1.85 and yet you ended up around $2.25. Can you guys just kind of give a little bit more description, a little bit more color on how you're thinking abo
componenttext: Just a clarification on the guidance, I think this time last year, you basically guided 2009 to about $1.85 and yet you ended up around $2.25. Can you guys just kind of give a little bit more description, a little bit more color on how you're thinking about your outlook for 2010?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: What I would say is that as we look to 2010, it's hard to look forward in a year that the U.S. economy and consumers continue to be under the pressure they're under and be real aggressive from a sales standpoint. At the same time, we're very enthused abou
componenttext: What I would say is that as we look to 2010, it's hard to look forward in a year that the U.S. economy and consumers continue to be under the pressure they're under and be real aggressive from a sales standpoint. At the same time, we're very enthused about the opportunity that we have in the Western U.S. with the implementation of our business model that will come to fruition this year as we open our distribution centers. We're hopeful that our comparable store sales and resulting earnings are better than what we would expect. But again, that's yet to be seen. The other factor is just purely from an expense standpoint. There's a lot of work to do, to do these conversions and there's a lot of expense related to these conversions and that's baked into our guidance. Certainly, we leverage any expense with great sales but I think that our sales guidance is reasonable and their resulting earnings would be reasonable based on that.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Scott, the two things I would add there, obviously, we're very excited about our results for 2009. A very good year. A couple of items, in relation to being so much higher above our initial guidance would be, one, we were successful through a lot of hard
componenttext: Scott, the two things I would add there, obviously, we're very excited about our results for 2009. A very good year. A couple of items, in relation to being so much higher above our initial guidance would be, one, we were successful through a lot of hard work from our merchandising staff and our field teams by changing over products earlier and pushing up the synergy dollars in 2009. We have a pretty good handle on where margin is going to be this year within a much narrower band. The second piece would be that when we did the 2009 guidance, LIBOR rates have bounced around quite a bit for the couple of months previous to that and that provided some tailwind for us too. LIBOR rates can't go much lower than they are now.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question is from the line of Mike Baker with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question is from the line of Mike Baker with Deutsche Bank.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is actually Adam in for Mike this morning. Two questions if I may. You talked a little bit about the difficult comparisons in December last year kind of impacting the comp. I was also hoping you could maybe discuss some other sort of factors in the q
componenttext: This is actually Adam in for Mike this morning. Two questions if I may. You talked a little bit about the difficult comparisons in December last year kind of impacting the comp. I was also hoping you could maybe discuss some other sort of factors in the quarter. One, obviously being modest-driven [ph]  that you discussed was down versus the second, third quarters of the year? But then also there's a competitor on the other day, discussing how they felt that they were not in a competitive position in the front half of the year, kind of change the pricing in the back half of the year. And then we saw another competitor this morning that was also little bit light on the topline. Wondering if you can maybe reconcile some of those comments for us, and how you look at the fourth quarter, really what was the major driver of comps at the low end there?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we saw in the fourth quarter, we had a relatively strong third quarter. Fourth quarter started off strong. December business from a comp store sales perspective soften some on tough comparisons. We had a good December last year. In 2007, we had a sof
componenttext: What we saw in the fourth quarter, we had a relatively strong third quarter. Fourth quarter started off strong. December business from a comp store sales perspective soften some on tough comparisons. We had a good December last year. In 2007, we had a soft December. We related the softer comps comparing 2008 of course, to the fact that consumers have been under a lot of pressure. Gas prices were up over 2008 and that there wasn't as much discretionary spending as what there would be and what there was available was being used as much as possible for holiday gifts and things like that. From a competitive standpoint, we've heard the same things that you've heard about the things our two competitors said. And as earlier mentioned, of course, they went through a process, I think, of adjusting their pricing. I think they're more competitive than they were before, retail. I don't think we've seen that so much on the commercial side. I don't know to what degree that affects us. We would be limited on the other competitor from an exposure standpoint to just the eastern half of the country. But we really haven't seen a material effect from that at this point. It's hard to measure that, of course. We work hard to keep our prices competitive and we never feel that we've gotten ourselves to a point that we're just done. It's a weekly process, a daily process. There's a whole team here that works on maintaining competitive retail prices and competitive prices for our repair shop partners and that's never a completed process. And there's never a time that we shop a complete line as some of our competitors having changed their prices. So we wouldn't have -- I don't think notice a significant change with the changes in the strategy or adjustments to some of our competitors say they've made.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: The 1,000 West Coast stores, I believe we're using estimates for those stores about 1.3 million per store broken down by about 1.1 million in retail, 200,000 commercial. Has that change at all significantly during this process of changing our products or
componenttext: The 1,000 West Coast stores, I believe we're using estimates for those stores about 1.3 million per store broken down by about 1.1 million in retail, 200,000 commercial. Has that change at all significantly during this process of changing our products or is that a decent estimate to use going forward?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think that's a pretty close point on average. The commercial business right now is growing pretty well on those stores. So over some period of time, the commercial business will grow and we don't expect the retail business of course to decline, we expec
componenttext: I think that's a pretty close point on average. The commercial business right now is growing pretty well on those stores. So over some period of time, the commercial business will grow and we don't expect the retail business of course to decline, we expect to grow that some too. But the commercial business right now is growing faster than the retail business.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Alan Rifkin with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Alan Rifkin with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Greg, now that the accelerated conversion of about 30 stores a week is well underway. Can you possibly shed some color on the performance of the stores in the weeks immediately following a conversion? And then also from an expense standpoint, are you beco
componenttext: Greg, now that the accelerated conversion of about 30 stores a week is well underway. Can you possibly shed some color on the performance of the stores in the weeks immediately following a conversion? And then also from an expense standpoint, are you becoming more efficient in the conversion process?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, first on this the performance of the stores following conversion. There's two ways of looking at it. One, you have to look at just the sales trends the store was on and two, you have to look at the comparisons that they're up against, so you don't g
componenttext: Well, first on this the performance of the stores following conversion. There's two ways of looking at it. One, you have to look at just the sales trends the store was on and two, you have to look at the comparisons that they're up against, so you don't get fooled by just the comp percentage that we may see. As I mentioned earlier, when we converted the Seattle stores, we started that process, I think it was November 9 and we had 8 stores that first week, and then we moved to 30 and then we had a couple of holidays in there. Those stores, we knew were coming up on an unusual winter storm they had last year that caused a real high spike in sales in those stores last year. So we knew we had some comparison issues. And looking at those stores sales trends, their sales really stayed on track and we didn't see much disruption from the conversion. Now you certainly, that first day, two days you have training issues, you're not as fast at point-of-sale. But these conversions really just aren't as disruptive as the ones we did in the center of the country. In Southern California, now that we've got some of the Moreno Valley stores under our belt. What we're seeing -- and again, business changes day to day, week to week based on a lot of different factors. But we're not seeing much change in the comp trend in those stores as they convert. They continue to operate very well under very normal weather in Southern California. There's very seldom a weather event in Southern California as you know. And Ted, you may have some comment.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Alan, I might add on the store expense side. Last year was a very task oriented year for all of CSK stores in the 1,000 stores in the West Coast. There was a lot of busy work going on as far as product changeovers. And plus preparing for the computer conv
componenttext: Alan, I might add on the store expense side. Last year was a very task oriented year for all of CSK stores in the 1,000 stores in the West Coast. There was a lot of busy work going on as far as product changeovers. And plus preparing for the computer conversions, the training and what we believe will see after they go on our system, the stores become more efficient. We'll leverage our payroll better through sales growth obviously, but also being able to implement our scheduling system on our computers in the store and fine tune our payroll costs down the West Coast this year.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just to make sure we answered the second part of your question on our ability to become more efficient in the actual conversion, there really isn't much to gain there. What we spend to put a tenured core O'Reilly team member on the plane traveling out the
componenttext: Just to make sure we answered the second part of your question on our ability to become more efficient in the actual conversion, there really isn't much to gain there. What we spend to put a tenured core O'Reilly team member on the plane traveling out there, the travel expenses, their payroll being out there and busier stores, you might have two that do this at the same time just to make sure there's plenty of training help for the store. There's really just not much that we can do to optimize that other than make sure we benefit from it as much as we can at the store being trained. So there's really not much to gain there. Our opportunity, as Ted said, is to just operate these stores more efficiently, which we're working towards through the ways that we manage payroll, the way we manage what we call a wage pyramid in the store to make sure that we have team members that are entry-level team members that are in the middle of the wage range. That are good parts specialist and then of course, the management of the store.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And one follow-up, Greg, if I may. With respect to this 141 Murray's stores, we certainly get a lot of questions from investors with respect to these stores. And even though it only represents by our estimates 2% to 3% of your revenues, are you still comm
componenttext: And one follow-up, Greg, if I may. With respect to this 141 Murray's stores, we certainly get a lot of questions from investors with respect to these stores. And even though it only represents by our estimates 2% to 3% of your revenues, are you still committed to these stores and are these Murray's stores still in fact profitable?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: They are profitable. As a whole, we're very committed and we've got one of our best operations guys up there running those. We have a divisional VP that's responsible for those as a very tenured O'Reilly manager member. He spends a lot of time in Detroit,
componenttext: They are profitable. As a whole, we're very committed and we've got one of our best operations guys up there running those. We have a divisional VP that's responsible for those as a very tenured O'Reilly manager member. He spends a lot of time in Detroit, a lot of time in Chicago. We're of course doing better in Chicago than we are in Detroit. Detroit's a very challenging economy. We're taking these stores through a very significant transition. These stores were very different than an O'Reilly Auto Part store. We focus on hard parts, application parts, automotive only merchandise, being a great supplier to the -- I'll call it the medium to heavy do-it-yourself-er and to commercial customers. And these stores were stores that carried a lot of -- they have a lot of automotive coverage of course not nearly to the degree that we would. But they had many ancillary products and non-automotive products that they would run promotions on at aggressive prices to bring traffic into the store and by taking those out, we've put ourselves in a comparison position to where we don't compare very well from a compare standpoint, yet on by-category basis, several of our hard parts categories are performing very well and we're very committed to turning these into very profitable auto parts stores over time and being a dominant factor in Chicago and in Detroit.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Alan, this is Tom. What I would add to that is because the Murray's stores are selling a lot of non-core products. Previous to conversion, their averages were higher than the company average because of those extra products. So when we look at the comp gro
componenttext: Alan, this is Tom. What I would add to that is because the Murray's stores are selling a lot of non-core products. Previous to conversion, their averages were higher than the company average because of those extra products. So when we look at the comp gross margin dollars in those stores, it's significantly better than the comp sales because a lot of those ancillary products did not carry very good gross margins.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Tony Cristello with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Tony Cristello with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess I have a question on -- now that the Seattle distribution center is up and you've got that market going, can you provide a little bit more color or detail on how you approach growing the commercial side now that you have sort of the replenishment
componenttext: I guess I have a question on -- now that the Seattle distribution center is up and you've got that market going, can you provide a little bit more color or detail on how you approach growing the commercial side now that you have sort of the replenishment up and what you're doing in that market to try and win new business?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Tony, actually most of the infrastructures been put in place. We started last year as far as looking at the staffing models in the store, realizing that we were going to have a better hard parts selection first of all, very, very soon, immediately. But th
componenttext: Tony, actually most of the infrastructures been put in place. We started last year as far as looking at the staffing models in the store, realizing that we were going to have a better hard parts selection first of all, very, very soon, immediately. But then we opened the DCs, we'd have the next layer of supply. So we started building stronger teams in the store from what we call them ISS, installer service specialist. Improving the hard parts mix, evaluating the territories around the stores and building new territories for more accounts. Their model was to call on a lot of the large accounts, but they overlooked a lot of small shops around the stores. So we sort of reengineered how they made sales calls, increased the number of TSMs. And like I said, it's a work in progress of implementing new installer service centers in the stores. We call them first call centers and in this consistency. And building relationships at the installer level, and it's working. We feel like the additional inventory now, particularly some of the brands that we have added towards the end of the year, last year and the last one, for instance, [indiscernible] we just changed over, which is a more additional line of oil filters and air filters. So we're really in good shape from a product standpoint. Obviously, with the new DCs, couldn't be in better shape with the supply chain. We'll just continue making consistent calls and give great customer service level. Dial-in to the competitive pricing, which there's different competitors in different markets. So you have to be competitive if you're going to get the business, and just grow the business. It's a process, it doesn't happen overnight because it is so relationship based. And quite honestly, the Seattle area had a pretty good foundation to grow from. They had a proportionally probably a better installer mix of business than what a lot of the Kragen and Checker stores did.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: So would you categorize that market as a better market than what you would see going into Greensboro in building out commercial?
componenttext: So would you categorize that market as a better market than what you would see going into Greensboro in building out commercial?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a bigger market. If you take a Greensboro for example, versus Seattle and Portland. So yes, there's more installer business. It's probably more fragmented with two steppers [ph]. So I'd say it's a stronger market just from a pure population count and
componenttext: It's a bigger market. If you take a Greensboro for example, versus Seattle and Portland. So yes, there's more installer business. It's probably more fragmented with two steppers [ph]. So I'd say it's a stronger market just from a pure population count and car count.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Michael Lasser with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Michael Lasser with Barclays Capital.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Since it seems like this will be a big year for investing in the conversion process. Can you perhaps quantify some of those costs, so we can have a better sense of what the longer-term margin outlook might be once you'll be done absorbing these expenses?
componenttext: Since it seems like this will be a big year for investing in the conversion process. Can you perhaps quantify some of those costs, so we can have a better sense of what the longer-term margin outlook might be once you'll be done absorbing these expenses? Is there any impact on the gross margin from the excess inventory investment that you made in the CSK stores?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: From a margin standpoint, where we get to an operating margin is going to be driven by where we can build the commercial business and the total average store sales. To leverage both the payrolls that we've put in from a commercial standpoint and a high fi
componenttext: From a margin standpoint, where we get to an operating margin is going to be driven by where we can build the commercial business and the total average store sales. To leverage both the payrolls that we've put in from a commercial standpoint and a high fixed coast of CSK. We're not prepared at this point to quantify what our payroll percentage is but after this year, we have a significant opportunity to get better on leveraging payroll. And there's a decent discrepancy between the core O'Reilly payroll percentage and what we're running at CSK now, which is kind of what you would expect. The second question on inventory, the answer to that is, no. But the margin that we've driven is based on the products that we sell and converting or really reducing our inventory, I call it rightsizing our inventory this year will not have a material impact on our gross margin percentages.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know that you disclosed the Schuck's numbers alongside the core OReilly numbers. And just to make sure I understand what the core, I guess pre-acquisition O'Reilly stores had done. From your discussions during the call, it sounds like the Schuck's nu
componenttext: I know that you disclosed the Schuck's numbers alongside the core OReilly numbers. And just to make sure I understand what the core, I guess pre-acquisition O'Reilly stores had done. From your discussions during the call, it sounds like the Schuck's numbers are probably under some pressure given the compare, such that the core O'Reilly stores probably did a little bit better than the combined number that you disclosed in the release?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is that materially better like half a point, a point something like or any of that?
componenttext: Is that materially better like half a point, a point something like or any of that?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would consider it not material and not to the extent that you described it.
componenttext: I would consider it not material and not to the extent that you described it.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, if you could discussed when during the year, you think the inventory growth rate will see an inflection point. Clearly, it sounds like by year end, I think your intimidating [ph] inventory might actually be down or at least pretty close
componenttext: And then secondly, if you could discussed when during the year, you think the inventory growth rate will see an inflection point. Clearly, it sounds like by year end, I think your intimidating [ph] inventory might actually be down or at least pretty close to flat. When do you think you'll start to work those numbers down?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: We're working on it right now. I think we'll see progress depending on what we have done here in the next 40 days or so. We may see some progress in the first quarter. I think by the end of the year, you would again see some slight increases as we open ne
componenttext: We're working on it right now. I think we'll see progress depending on what we have done here in the next 40 days or so. We may see some progress in the first quarter. I think by the end of the year, you would again see some slight increases as we open new stores and distribution centers that we'll see a dip before then going back up to a slight increase at the end of the year.

And Tom, I think you alluded earlier there's still some pretty good opportunities on the COGS side from purchasing. Can you just refresh us is that still sort of a 70, 30 split between COGS versus SG&A in light of some of the other opportunities you have in payroll that you just mentioned?

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: In our prepared comments, we pointed to $25 million of incremental buying synergies this year. When you look at our run rate of gross margin last year, you can see when the major deals got done and our acquisition costs got been [ph] fused. So most of tha
componenttext: In our prepared comments, we pointed to $25 million of incremental buying synergies this year. When you look at our run rate of gross margin last year, you can see when the major deals got done and our acquisition costs got been [ph] fused. So most of that will fall in the first quarter. From a headquarters, SG&A purely synergy standpoint, we have opportunities this year and part of that is going to be offset by investing in district managers and TSMs, as Ted discussed earlier to really get the feel of the operational support they need to grow the business.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010

componenttext: And then just quickly as a follow-up on the comps side. Obviously, some deceleration from the 53 to the 27, just looking at a very a high level. And then secondarily, DIY versus DIFM, if you could give us a feel there from where you shake out?

componenttext: Well, our DIFM business is growing a little better than what our DIY business is. Ticket count in average, I think were both -- if you compared it to the third quarter, I think both would be affected a little bit, is that correct Tom?

componenttext: Yes, that's correct.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, to kind to add to the comment I made earlier about consumers just being under pressure and the holiday season putting already strapped consumers under more pressure. I think was manifested for us in a slightly lower ticket average and of course,
componenttext: I think, to kind to add to the comment I made earlier about consumers just being under pressure and the holiday season putting already strapped consumers under more pressure. I think was manifested for us in a slightly lower ticket average and of course, just some decreased traffic as compared to the third quarter.

componenttext: We -- for the first in several years, CSK from a retail standpoint is got a hard parts inventory, competitive pricing, which we should see some nice growth from that. it won't happen overnight. It's going to take a while. Kind of remake the image of their availability and competitive pricing to retail but it will happen. Slowly and surely.

headline: O'Reilly Automotive Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 18, 2010
componenttextpreview: Incrementally most likely, Scott, we'll get to the 80, 20, 75, 25, in what time that happens, is a little bit of an unknown now. But over some period of time, most of the stores out there would probably be similar to what we are in core O'Reilly with that
componenttext: Incrementally most likely, Scott, we'll get to the 80, 20, 75, 25, in what time that happens, is a little bit of an unknown now. But over some period of time, most of the stores out there would probably be similar to what we are in core O'Reilly with that approximately 50/50 mix. Although there are, some of the locations that are in locations that will always drive more retail than what they do commercial. So if you look at those stores as a whole, we may -- you'll never get them to a 50/50 but most stores will eventually get to that.

componenttext: And just more specifically in gross margin, as you think -- obviously had a fair amount of experience  overseeing how the converted stores ramp. If the stores on the West Coast ramp like you would expect, and I think you had maybe said, Checker is a decent example for that. How should we think about it? What have you planned as the mix headwind on gross margins as you get toward the end of 2010? Maybe just thinking about 2011 as the full year. In your plan, what does that mean in terms of gross margin mix headwind to overcome? Because I think you said, you thought you might be able to maintain this gross margin rate?
